text: To post a payment, you can click Payments in the navigation bar and then Create a transaction. On the New Transaction page, enter the deposit date and the transaction amount. Start typing the payer name and then select it from the list. You can also enter the claim number.
For more information click this: https://help.zollonline.com/billing/Content/Videos.htm?wchannelid=m8t21u1viq&wmediaid=0jgpktzvng

text.text: How do I begin the process of posting a single payment in the system?

text: To begin the process of posting a single payment in the system, you can click Payments in the navigation bar and then Create a transaction. On the New Transaction page, enter the deposit date and the transaction amount. Start typing the payer name and then select it from the list. You can also enter the claim number.

text.text: Where can I find the option to create a new transaction for posting a single payment?

text: To create a new transaction for posting a single payment, you can click Payments in the navigation bar and then Create a transaction. On the New Transaction page, enter the deposit date and the transaction amount. Start typing the payer name and then select it from the list. You can also enter the claim number.

text.text: What information do I need to input on the New Transaction page before proceeding?

text: To post a payment, you can click Payments in the navigation bar and then Create a transaction. On the New Transaction page, enter the deposit date and the transaction amount. Start typing the payer name and then select it from the list. You can also enter the claim number.

text.text: What information do I need to input on the New Transaction page before proceeding?

text: To post a payment, you can click Payments in the navigation bar and then Create a transaction. On the New Transaction page, enter the deposit date and the transaction amount. Start typing the payer name and then select it from the list. You can also enter the claim number.

text.text: Can you explain the significance of entering the transaction number during payment posting?

text: The transaction number is the check number or payment identifier from the EOB. It is used to identify the transaction.

text.text: What should I input in the transaction date field if the transaction type is not a check?

text: If the transaction type is not a check, you should enter the EOB date in the transaction date field.

text.text: How do I apply a payment to an individual claim during payment posting?

text: To apply a payment to an individual claim, you can enter the claim number. If you know the number, start typing the number and select it from the list.

text.text: What steps do I follow if I don't know the claim number but need to apply a payment?

text: If you don't know the claim number, you can click the search icon and enter the customer's name and service date. After you enter the claim number, the information for the claim displays. If this information is correct, scroll down to the bottom and look at the Unallocated field. This field should read 0.00.

text.text: How can I search for a claim using the customer's name and service date?

text: You can also search for claims using the Line-item Editor page. On the Line-item Editor page, click the icon and search using only one field such as the last name or narrow the search by entering information in multiple fields. You can also combine different search attributes to narrow down your results, such as using "L" in "Last name" along with a date of birth.

text.text: Once the claim information is displayed, what should I verify before proceeding with posting the transaction?

text: To apply a payment to an individual claim, you can enter the claim number. If you know the number, start typing the number and select it from the list. If you don't know the claim number, you can click the search icon and enter the customer's name and service date. After you enter the claim number, the information for the claim displays. If this information is correct, scroll down to the bottom and look at the Unallocated field. This field should read 0.00.

text.text: What action should I take if the Unallocated field does not read zero after entering the claim number?

text: If the Unallocated field does not read zero, you must reconcile the difference. Once the unallocated amount reads zero, you can click Post transaction.

text.text: Can I proceed with posting the transaction if the Unallocated field is not zero?

text: You can't post the denial until the unallocated amount is zero.

text.text: How do I reconcile any difference in the Unallocated field before posting the transaction?

text: To reconcile the difference, you can click the search icon and enter the customer's name and service date.

text.text: What should I do once the Unallocated field reads zero to complete the transaction po

text: Once the unallocated amount reads zero, you can click Post transaction.

text.text: Is it possible to review the transaction details before finalizing the posting process?

text: You can click Finish later to review the information you just posted. After posting the transaction, a note cannot be edited but can be removed.

To post a payment, you can click Payments in the navigation bar and then Create a transaction. On the New Transaction page, enter the deposit date and the transaction amount. Start typing the payer name and then select it from the list. You can also select the type of payment and enter the transaction number, which is the check number or payment identifier from the EOB. If transaction type was a check, enter the date the check was issued in the transaction date field. For other transaction types, enter the EOB date.
For more information click this: https://help.zollonline.com/billing/Content/Videos.htm?wchannelid=m8t21u1viq&wmediaid=0jgpktzvng

Start typing the payer name and then select it from the list. You can also select the type of payment and enter the transaction number, which is the check number or payment identifier from the EOB. If transaction type was a check, enter the date the check was issued in the transaction date field. For other transaction types, enter the EOB date.
